revision.text:
The '''1200-ton Oil Fuel Lighter''' was a class of [[Fuel oil|oil fuel]] [[Lighter (barge)|lighter]]s built for the [[Royal Australian Navy]] between 1940 and 1946.<ref>Wilson, Michael; Australia. Navy Office. Naval Historical Records Section; Australia. Navy Office. Public Affairs (1994) (in English), Profile No. 4, Royal Australian Navy 21st century warships, Topmill, Marrickville, N.S.W, {{ISBN|0-646-22841-2}}</ref>
==Design== The lighters were {{convert|186|ft|m}} in length and {{convert|36|ft|m}} beam and cost about £38,940 each to build.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17651419 |title=Oil Fuel Lighter for Navy, £38,940 Contract Let|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |work=The Sydney Morning Herald, Friday 19 January 1940, p.13. |publisher= |accessdate=22 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article42221438 |title=Tender for Lighter, Largest in Commonwealth, Brisbane firm successful.|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |work=Cairns Post, Saturday 20 January 1940, p.13. |publisher= |accessdate=22 December 2011}}</ref>
==Oil fuel lighters== *OFL 1201, ''Rocklea'', built by [[Evans Deakin and Company]], [[Brisbane]] *OFL 1202, built by [[Mort's Dock]] *OFL 1203, built by Mort's Dock *OFL 1204, built by [[Poole and Steel]], sunk for target practice in October 1985. *OFL 1205 *OFL 1206, built at the [[Williamstown Naval Dockyard]], was completed on 12 October 1945, and was sold into mercantile service in 1968. Sunk as a target in 1993, to form part of an artificial reef. *OFL 1207, built at the Williamstown Naval Dockyard, was completed on 15 February 1946, and was still in service in the late 1980s. *OFL 1208, ''Karpoint'', built by Evans Deakin and Company, Brisbane
==References== {{reflist}}
